sentences.sentence: Canadians are living through two health-care crises: COVID, which dominates the headlines, but also unacceptably long wait times for virtually all medical services.
In 2021, Canadians could expect to wait an estimated 25.6 weeks on average - essentially half a year - between referral from a family physician and medically necessary treatment.

Though lengthened by COVID, these waits have far more to do with long-standing failures of domestic policy than with the global pandemic.This year marks the 30th edition of the Fraser Institute's annual survey(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/waiting-your-turn-wait-times-for-health-care-in-canada-2021) of physicians.

First designed and conducted in British Columbia(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/waiting-your-turn-1990.pdf) with assistance from the province's medical association, by 1993 the survey had expanded to cover all 10 provinces across 12 core medical specialties.
Unfortunately, data collected over these three decades reveal a steady deterioration in timely access to care.

In fact, this year's average wait is the longest in the survey's history and more than 2.5 times longer that the 9.3 weeks identified in the first national survey in 1993.Across provinces this year, physicians in Nova Scotia reported the longest total wait - 53.2 weeks: more than a year - while those in Ontario reported the shortest, at "only" 18.5 weeks.

Across Canada, patients waited longest between referral and treatment for neurosurgery (49.2 weeks) and orthopedic surgery (46.1 weeks), while shorter waits were reported for cancer care radiation (3.7 weeks) and medical oncology (4.4 weeks).

Taking all 12 specialities into account, physicians report that patients waited six weeks longer for treatment after consultation with a specialist than is clinically reasonable.It's important to note that while these wait lists are largely for procedures technically considered "elective" (i.e., scheduled or planned treatment, in contrast to emergencies), they are all "medically necessary" and include treatments ranging from scheduled cataract removals to life-saving cardiac care.

Excessive wait times can increase the stress and strain on patients and loved ones and lead to poorer health outcomes for patients, including even death.It is important to stress that although the pandemic has contributed to longer wait times over the last two years it does not account for almost three decades of documented wait-time increases.

In 2019(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/waiting-your-turn-wait-times-for-health-care-in-canada-2019), a year before the pandemic began, Canadians were already waiting 20.9 weeks on average for care.Gwyn Morgan: We're still a long way from normal(https://financialpost.com/opinion/gwyn-morgan-were-still-a-long-way-from-normal)Matthew Lau: EDI also spells DIE, the likely result of woke medicine(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-edi-also-spells-die-the-likely-result-of-woke-medicine)Matthew Lau: How not to help the wretched of the Earth(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-how-not-to-help-the-wretched-of-the-earth)Unfortunately, COVID also created a more challenging research environment, which resulted in just a nine per cent national response rate from physicians for our wait-times survey, lower than in previous years.

However, this response rate remains in line with other(https://surveys.cma.ca/ ) population-based surveys, such as the Canadian Medical Association's Physician Workforce Survey, which had a response rate of 12.8 per cent in 2019(https://surveys.cma.ca/en/permalink?id=survey119), pre-pandemic.

It would be a mistake to ignore(https://vancouversun.com/opinion/opinion-survey-critics-unwilling-to-acknowledge-wait-time-problem-in-canada)the experiences of the 1,178 physicians who responded to the Fraser Institute's survey this year.Moreover, other organizations have reported similar findings.

In 2020(https://www.cihi.ca/sites/default/files/document/how-canada-compares-cmwf-survey-2020-chartbook-en.pdf), the Commonwealth Fund ranked Canada at the bottom of 11 international health-care systems for speedy specialist appointments (i.e., under four weeks) and elective surgeries (under four months).

It found similar results(https://www.cihi.ca/en/commonwealth-fund-survey-2016) in 2016, long before the pandemic.We must of course remain focused on combatting COVID and supporting the health-care workers who've led us through this storm.

But we should also learn from other countries that also provide universal health care but don't subject patients to the long wait times Canadians regularly experience.Countries such as Germany, Switzerland and the Netherlands all approach universal health care differently than Canada.

They form functional partnerships with their private(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/understanding-universal-health-care-reform-options-private-insurance.pdf) sectors to: provide timely, high-quality care; incentivize responsible use of health-care resources through cost-sharing(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/sites/default/files/select-cost-sharing-in-universal-health-care-countries.pdf) (with protections for vulnerable populations); and fund their hospitals based on current levels of activity(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/understanding-universal-health-care-reform-options-activity-based-funding), not historical formulae, so as to expedite surgical care.

Although the pandemic has also challenged them these countries will likely return to a much better "normal" once it has passed.If Canadians hope to experience wait times more like those in other universal health-care countries, Canadian health policy needs fundamental reform.Mackenzie Moir and Bacchus Barua are analysts at the Fraser Institute.
